Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2011 01:53PM GreenSeaTurtle wrote: Hi meme, It sounds like fibrocystic changes maybe? Did your previous mammo's state how dense your breasts are? The thing with dense breasts and fibrocystic changes is that it makes it very difficult for mammo's to see everything going on. Ultrasounds are better but MRI's are the best at 'seeing' everything. I would get the diagnostic mammo and an US done. Be sure to explain the new lumps and bumps you are seeing. Here's some websites that might help: www.lef.org/protocols/prtcl-145.shtml www.cancer.org/Healthy/FindCancerEarly/WomensHealth/Non-CancerousBreastConditions/non-cancerous-breast-conditions-fibrocystic-changes www.halls.md/breast/density.html www.imaginis.com/breast-health/benign-breast-conditions-1#nipple-discharge The last website has lots of information on it, just read through the whole thing. Take care!
Posts.Title: Ridge of bumps meme31 meme31

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2011 02:11PM GreenSeaTurtle wrote: Continuing my thoughts :)...an MRI is the best tool for dense breasts because it is so sensitive but that also means it has a lot of false positives which can lead to biopsies that turn out b9. Now I would rather go through the biopsies then to not know what is going on with my dense breasts. One of my breasts has lots of fibrocystic stuff going on in it. I've got a fibroadenoma, sclerosing adenosis, cysts and hyperplasia. But only on the one side. It's especially lumpy and bumpy. The imaginis website on my earlier post talks about fibroadenomas. You might need to get a biopsy for peace of mind dependion on how your other tests go, and whether you get a doc you trust or not. Hang on to your balls! You've got to be your own advocate and fight to get the tests you need! Oh, I also had high grade precancerous lesions on my cervix! I had had many surgeries to get rid of it. Eventually, because it just kept coming back, and because I was having some other stuff going on, I had a hysterectomy (but I had them leave my ovaries) I was 24 years old for my first cervical surgery, and 33 when I had the hysto. Managed to have 3 kids during that time :) Take care (again)

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2011 05:28PM GreenSeaTurtle wrote: I had a ductogram as an evaluation tool, not biopsy but I have heard of it being done for biopsy. You lay on a table, they swab the nipple, put numbing cream on it and then they gently press on your breast to see what duct the discharge is coming out of. They then insert this little L shaped catheter into the duct(this can take awhile- the ducts are tiny and hard to find). The catheter is attached to a long tube with a syringe of dye on the other end. They will fill the duct up slowly until you feel pain or pressure. Now, for me at this point the doctor taped the tube and syringe to my side and I had to walk over and get a mammogram so they could see the duct. They took several shots at different angles. I had some discomfort, more like a feeling of pressure, in the breast when it was filled with dye. The only problem I had was I fainted while holding my breath during the mammogram and smacked into a wall. I have a heart condition and I guess having the pressure inside my breast and then holding my breath was enough to trigger a vasovagal episode. I have had lots of mammograms without any problems whatsoever. It was kind of embarrassing. Although the nurses laughed because the first thing I asked when I came to was whether the catheter had fallen out since it took so long to get it in (it hadn't, yay). I went on to do the rest of the mammogram.  The only biopsy I've had was a vacuum assisted core needle biopsy which is on a much smaller scale than excisional. They sent me home with a pressure bandage on that I wore for 2 days. I still wore a tight fitting sports bra for weeks after, and I iced it every 20 minutes for 2 days after. I was told no Advil, Motrin, Aleve, etc.; no vitamin e, and no fish oil supplements for one week before the biopsy. Good luck and keep pressure on the breast- you don't want to end up like a lopsided Dolly Parton!

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2011 03:08PM GreenSeaTurtle wrote: First, I don't think you wasted anyone's time! It really is hard to know what is going on and I think your doctor is wonderful to have referred you for an MRI. And if it is benign results- Yay! It's always better to be proactive about your health. Also, you now have a good baseline set of images to check against any future problems. Secondly, there are many stories on this board alone about women who totally trusted their doctor, didn't get further imaging done, and ended up with later stage cancer than they would have had if they had had a doctor that listened to them and did more tests. Doctor's, unfortunately, are human and make mistakes. So I say- good for you for standing up for yourself!
Posts.Title: Having Doubts Curiousone Curiousone

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2011 01:20PM GreenSeaTurtle wrote: My appointment went really well. She answered all my questions and really took her time to explain everything to me. She said I am benign. There is nothing to worry about right now. Not maybe, not seems like, but just benign. My nipple has been inverting because of some of the tissue (sclerosing adenosis, microcysts and other fibrocystic stuff) going on behind my nipple. She could pull the nipple out and it would stay out for a little bit before slowly retracting in. She said that is a good sign. If it was pulled deeply into the breast and she couldn't pull it out would be something to worry about. Or if it pulled to the side or started pointing to the ground. She also told me what to watch out for. Re: the discharge- she couldn't get any at the appointment but she said that she worries about discharge that is clear, runny, or bloodtinged, more than the thick white stuff I had. She did a very thorough exam feeling for any lumps. I haven't been that felt up since I was in high school! She took the time to look over my films with me and read over the pathology report to me. She was so comforting and at the same time straight with her information. She does not see the need for any kind of surgery at this time. She does want me to go ahead and have my 6 month MRI, which is actually only 3 months away now. She wants to check the stability of some random clusters that I have and also all the stuff they found around my fibroadenoma, and the fibroadenoma itself. At that point we'll meet again and talk it over. She did say that I have dense breasts and the MRI is the best diagnostic tool to use in my case (she did say that my breast center was very thorough with me since I had mammo's, US, biopsy, ductogram and then MRI). I asked if the dense breast tissue could hide things in an MRI and she said that the MRI that I had, with the injected dye, would catch everything except something really really small and very slow growing.  And with the mammo and US images along with the MRI she could get all the views of everything going on in my breast. The only other thing was she sent me to get my prolactin levels checked to see if that was what was causing the discharge. She told me she didn't think that was it but she wanted to get that test checked off the list. It is not cancer causing the discharge but it could be the stuff going on behind my nipple and my body dealing with it. It was a long appointment with a lot of information and I left there much more at ease. I feel more in control because she gave me so much information about me and my breast specifically. I'm taking some nice deep breaths...

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2011 03:23PM GreenSeaTurtle wrote: No worries- those are benign results. They do mean that she will need mammograms or MRI's more often to make sure it stays stable. These findings do slightly raise her risk of getting cancer sometime in her lifetime (mostly the atypia cells).It does not mean that she is guaranteed to get cancer. Make sure she is vigilant in getting her imaging exactly when the doctor says to. Here are some websites with more information for you: www.cancer.org/Healthy/FindCancerEarly/WomensHealth/Non-CancerousBreastConditions/non-cancerous-breast-conditions-hyperplasia This website has a lot of information in it. Follow the links at the top of the page. www.imaginis.com/breast-health/benign-breast-conditions-1#overview-breast-tissue-changes Take care.

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 05:21AM GreenSeaTurtle wrote: Hi merrysee, I'm currently going through lots of tests trying to see what is going on with my left breast. But my journey started because my nipple starting inverting and I also had thick discharge from it (and my last pregnancy was 6 years ago). The doctors have told me that a nipple that is starting to invert could have many causes, not just cancer. It could be a papilloma, a fibroadenoma (both abnormal growths but not cancer). It could also be that a ligament in the breast has shortened for totally benign reasons. Also, it might be they way your breast is responding to pregnancy. They change a lot with all the hormones running around and getting ready for milk production. I would keep an eye on it but don't worry about it unless you have a secondary symptom come up. They can only do an ultrasound on you right now since you are pregnant. Otherwise they would do a mammogram or MRI. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2011 01:40PM GreenSeaTurtle wrote: Before my biopsy I was also told no Tylenol, Advil, Aleve etc. But I was also told no Vitamin E, and no fish oils of any kind for 1 week before hand. The nurse says that all those keep the blood from clotting easily. They wanted to do an immediate biopsy but had to delay it since I was taking Aleve, the Vitamin E was in my multi-vitamin and I take extra fish oil supplements. I figure better safe than sorry!

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2011 01:30PM GreenSeaTurtle wrote: I second getting the second opinion. Go to a reputable breast clinic. I was told that even if they think it's a fibroadenoma, if it's grown they have to biopsy it to confirm that it is just a fibro and not something else. The only way to truly diagnose what a solid lump is is by biopsying them. If it is a cyst, which they could tell by ultrasound, then they should drain it since it is causing you discomfort. Be sure to tell your doctor why you want a second opinion. He/she should know what a bad doctor he sent you to! You should not have been treated like that. Take care, and stay strong!
